awd_titl_txt: SoCS: Collaborative Research: Local Community Crowdsourcing of Physical-World Tasks with Myrmex
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will design and implement "Myrmex", a novel crowdsourcing system for physical-world tasks. For example, an elderly community member could use Myrmex for help getting mail from a remote post office, as the system would assign the task to a participant who routinely passes that way. Myrmex leverages the capacity of computers (monitoring, matching participants to tasks) to facilitate human activity (assigning and performing tasks). The project will: 1) develop new privacy-preserving methods for location and context tracking; 2) design and implement incentives for continuous use of a new social system; and 3) create and implement models of best times and places to notify and offer tasks for participants.
 
Broader impacts: The Myrmex system will help strengthen bonds and connectivity within a community and provide assistance for community members for running their daily lives. Matching tasks and people based on locations and paths will also help conserve resources and benefit the environment due to the reduced travel miles needed to perform a task.  The project will provide multidisciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate students. It will also provide the research community with an anonymized dataset of human mobility patterns and task activities, and tools to analyze human behavior.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This research explored ways of encouraging collaboration on tasks through crowds and online communities. Some of the studies looked at  the ways mobile applications could interrupt and encourage online participants to help each other with tasks, including physical world tasks such as picking up food or medical items. More general issues were also addressed, including how people plan and collaborate, as well as which collaboration patterns lead to better results for individuals and communities,  Activities of the research included building mobile apps, performing experiments that collected locational and other data, and analyzing data collected from experiments and from online collaborative communities. 

Intellectual Merit

The project led to new theories about the ways people coordinate and collaborate. Twenty papers were produced, including three papers for the conference Computer Supported Cooperative Work & Social Computing, and one paper in the journal MIS Quarterly. 

Broader impacts

The findings of the research may be useful to the designers of online communities that encourage the performance of physical tasks for each other, such as time banks. The findings may also be useful for those engaged in creating rapid community response to natural disasters such as flooding. More generally, the research may be useful to designers of online peer production systems. The research supported one Ph.D. student all the way through to her final year, and involved three master's students, as well as five undergraduate students. Moreover, results of the research became part of the curriculum in an undergraduate class in social network analysis.
